title: 110_s2676
content: The Act may be cited as the "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2008" and includes provisions for consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma to establish gaming operations on certain lands within or adjacent to their former reservation boundaries. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify exceptions for gaming establishments on Indian lands in Oklahoma, subject to consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles of the land. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow gaming establishments on Indian lands in Oklahoma, with the condition that it benefits the tribe and its members, and does not negatively impact nearby entities within 60 miles. The approval of the state Governor and legislative body is required for the Secretary's determination to be valid. The Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2008 exempts land with existing gaming facilities from certain regulations. The primary nexus for Indian tribes' land must be within the state where the tribe is primarily located, as determined by the Secretary. The geographic, social, and historical nexus to land of an Indian tribe is determined by ownership or trust by the United States, location within designated geographical areas for financial assistance and social services, including reservations. The Indian tribe's geographical area is designated during the Federal acknowledgment process, where more than 50% of members reside. It must be within the historical residence area determined by the Secretary or in a different State. The Indian tribe must conduct gaming activities on 1 contiguous parcel of Indian lands within the boundaries of their last recognized reservation in a State other than Oklahoma. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to include provisions for class II gaming on Indian lands before or after the date of enactment. The Indian tribe requested that the land be taken into trust for the purpose of conducting class II gaming activities. Amendments were made to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to include provisions for class II gaming on Indian lands. The Indian tribe requested that the land be taken into trust for the purpose of conducting class II gaming activities on Indian lands before or after the date of enactment of the subparagraph. The Indian tribe requested the land be taken into trust for class III gaming activities, defining 'State' as the Governor and legislative body. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION AND APPROVAL. The Chairman's powers under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act are amended to include approving or disapproving the involvement in a gaming activity of individuals with the highest financial interest. The Commission's powers are also amended to include the authority to regulate gaming activities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to give the Chairman the power to approve or disapprove individuals with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. The Commission is granted authority to regulate gaming activities and conduct background investigations on those involved. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant the Commission authority to regulate gaming activities and conduct background investigations on individuals with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. The amendments also include provisions for minimum internal control standards for class II and class III gaming. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant the Commission authority to regulate gaming activities and conduct background investigations on key individuals involved in tribal gaming enterprises. Commission funding is also addressed in the amendments. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2717(a)(2)(B)) is amended to change the percentage to $16,000,000. SEC. 5. CHANGING USE OF INDIAN LANDS: Amends the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming. The Act and its amendments will not impact any existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulated under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
